conclusion: Analyze forces on blocks A and B to determine slipping conditions.
Block B is pushed by a horizontal force and is in close contact with block A.
The contact surface between A and B is vertical.
Coefficient of kinetic friction between A and B is μ1, and between A and ground is μ2.
Normal force on B equals weight of B due to no vertical acceleration.
Equilibrium condition for B: frictional force equals weight of B.
Frictional force on B is μ1 times normal force from A.
Normal force from A on B equals weight of B.
Equating frictional force expressions gives mB = mA/μ1.
Normal force on A is sum of weights of A and B.
Frictional force on A equals force F.
Frictional force on A is μ2 times normal force from ground.
Substitute mB = mA/μ1 into frictional force equation for A.
Factor out mA g from the equation.
Simplify to find F = mA g μ2 (1 + 1/μ1).
Mass ratio of A to B is μ1/(μ1 - 1).
